message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of a painless genital ulcer, inguinal lymphadenopathy, and recent unprotected sex with multiple partners suggest the most likely diagnosis is syphilis. The FTA-ABS test is the standard confirmatory test for syphilis. The VDRL test is also used to screen for syphilis, but it can give false positives in other conditions. Swabbing the chancre and performing a saline wet mount can help diagnose herpes simplex virus, and the Frei test is not used in the diagnosis of syphilis.

The VDRL test is also used for syphilis diagnosis, but it has a high false positive rate. The Frei test is no longer used for syphilis diagnosis. Swabbing the chancre and performing a saline wet mount would not be helpful for syphilis diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a single genital ulcer, inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a history of unprotected sex with multiple partners, which is most likely indicative of syphilis. The FTA-ABS test is the most specific test for diagnosing syphilis. The VDRL test is less specific and may lead to false positives. Swabbing the chancre and performing a saline wet mount is used to diagnose other sexually transmitted infections like gonorrhea and chlamydia. The Frei test is not a commonly used test for diagnosing sexually transmitted infections.
